title: 105_hr3478
content: The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" aims to settle the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Agreement, Animas-la plata project, and Dolores project. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Dolores Project and Tribe/Tribes as per Public Law 100-585. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE COLORADO UTE INDIAN WATER RIGHTS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1988. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to include the construction of a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. The Animas-La Plata Project includes a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet, a pumping plant, and a reservoir inlet conduit. Municipal and industrial water allocations are made to the Southern Ute Tribe, with an average annual depletion not to exceed 16,525 acre-feet of water. Water allocations are designated for the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, and Navajo Nation, with specified annual depletion limits. The water allocations include 16,525 acre-feet for the Southern Ute Tribe, 2,340 acre-feet for the Navajo Nation, 10,400 acre-feet for the San Juan Water Commission, and 2,600 acre-feet for the Animas-La Plata Conservancy District. The Animas-La Plata Conservancy District is allocated 2,600 acre-feet of water annually. Tribal construction costs for the project are nonreimbursable. Nontribal water capital obligations will be satisfied upon full payment. The nontribal municipal and industrial water capital repayment obligations for the Animas-La Plata Project shall be satisfied by the San Juan Water Commission, Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District, and the State of Colorado, totaling $29,000,000. The State of Colorado will contribute $16,000,000 towards the cost-sharing obligation for the Animas-La Plata Project, as part of the Agreement in Principle Concerning the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement. The Animas-La Plata Project includes nonreimbursable costs for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources protection, and fish and wildlife enhancement. Tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use are allocated from the project. The Secretary will pay for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for municipal and industrial water allocated to a Tribe from the Animas-La Plata Project or the Dolores Project until the water is used by the Tribe. The Tribe is not required to reimburse these costs. The Tribe is not required to reimburse the Secretary for the payment of any costs related to the allocation of water. Repayment of the Tribe's pro rata share of construction costs for the Dolores Project will commence when the water allocation is first used by the Tribe. The Tribe will start repaying its share of construction costs for the Dolores Project and bear annual operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for the allocated water. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to provide water allocations to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado or the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 provide water allocations to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico, with specific annual depletion limits. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocate water to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico, with an annual depletion limit of 780 acre-feet of water. Additional depletions may be allowed under the Endangered Species Act, with allocations made among beneficiaries according to an agreement. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocate water to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico. The Secretary shall transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries upon request from the State Engineer, in accordance with applicable State law. Upon request, the Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries to fulfill the purposes of the Animas La-Plata Project. The Final Supplement to the Environmental Impact Statement from April 1996 will be treated accordingly. The Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries for the Animas La-Plata Project, with permit number 2883 dated May 1, 1956. The Final Supplement to the April 1996 Environmental Impact Statement and the February 19, 1996, Final Biological Opinion will satisfy requirements under the Endangered Species Act. The Final Biological Opinion of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service dated February 19, 1996, for the Animas-La Plata Project is sufficient to meet requirements under the Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The U.S.C. 1251 et seq. addresses amendments related to the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, completion of construction of specified facilities, and an aggregate depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water as approved in a biological opinion. This subsection does not impact the construction of facilities not mentioned. The final settlement involves providing water to the Tribes as approved in a biological opinion, without affecting the construction of facilities not mentioned or any use of water not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The final settlement provides water to the Tribes as approved in a biological opinion, settling tribal claims to water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. Nothing in the settlement affects the Tribes' water rights on other streams and rivers mentioned in the Agreement. The final settlement provides water to the Tribes as approved in a biological opinion, settling tribal claims to water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. The Tribes retain water rights on other streams and rivers mentioned in the Agreement, excluding the Animas and La Plata Rivers. The Attorney General of the United States will file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7 in Colorado to amend the final consent decree regarding water rights under Colorado law. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of the Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation. The Indian Reservation is described in various Department of the Interior and Related Agencies Appropriations Acts from 1991 to 1994. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as referenced in various Department of the Interior and Related Agencies Appropriations Acts from 1991 to 1995, is addressed in subsection (b) of the Colorado Ute Indian Reservation. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado for the Animas-La Plata Project can be used for funding components not described in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988.
